text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with thai style sweet chilli sauce
that's right as promised i'm gonna show
you my take on what i consider one of
the greatest dipping sauces of all time
generally this sauce is made in one of
two ways
there's the thinner quicker uncooked
version and then there's a slightly more
complex cooked thicker version well this
is actually a hybrid between the two and
i think the results are spectacular i
mean this stuff just has everything you
could possibly want and i'm not just
talking about it in a dipping sauce
i'm talking about in life so i'm very
excited to show you this and we will
begin with the star of the show our thai
chilies also known as Birds Eye chilies
which is kind of weird I mean if you're
a bird in your eye looks like this you
better get that checked out
as you can see we have a few different
colors here but these are all the same
pepper the green ones simply haven't
ripened to be red yet so they all start
out green and then kind of turn yellow
and then orange and then eventually red
which these really haven't yet maybe
it's too early in the season and by the
way the redder they are the hotter they
are so ideally these would be all red
but no worries these are still going to
work so I picked out the ripe is ones I
could find and to prep these all we need
to do is mince them up very finely and
we're not going to see these in fact I'm
not even sure if that's possible and if
it is is going to take you forever so we
don't worry about the seeds here we just
chopped everything up nice and fine and
if you're smart wear some gloves for
this I didn't but you should these
things are hot is in really hot
they're probably closest in heat to like
a habanero so please be careful
especially if you don't wear gloves do
not be touching your you-know-what so we
will go ahead and finely chop up a
couple tablespoons of chili peppers and
then as far as the rest of the fresh
ingredients go we're also going to want
a whole bunch of finely crushed garlic
as well as some fresh lime juice and
then once those fresh ingredients are
prepped we can move on to the non fresh
cooked portion of the program so into a
sauce pan we will dump a half cup of
good old-fashioned fresh cold water and
then we will follow that up with some
white distilled vinegar and yes
technically you can use another kind of
vinegar I mean you are the Fat Boy slim
of this Nam gym but the vinegar in this
is for acidity not for flavor which is
why something neutral works best and
then besides the vinegar we also want a
couple tablespoons of Asian fish sauce
which is absolutely mandatory here in my
opinion you really can't make this sauce
without it I mean you can replace the
saltiness with other stuff but it just
will not have that same savory funk and
then we're definitely going to need
something sweet to balance all the heat
so we will go ahead and add some brown
sugar which if you want this to be more
authentic would be palm sugar but the
brown sugar does work very nicely and
then next up I'm going to add a spoon of
ketchup that is for flavor color and so
I get some emails from Thailand so we'll
add a little bit of that and then to
hedge our bets and give us a one-two
punch of chilli goodness in addition to
the fresh Thai chilies I'm also going to
add a couple spoons of preserved chilies
in the very easy to obtain form of sound
bottle which reminds me this sauce can
be made with any combination of fresh
dried or preserved chilies and I will go
over a few of those options on the blog
and then last but not least we're going
to finish this off with 1 spoon of
cornstarch and then we'll take a whisk
and mix that up and by the way we're
saving a step here usually that
cornstarch is mixed with water and stir
it into the sauce at the end but this is
going to work just the same we're going
to save a step so we will stir that
until that cornstarch disappears at
which point this is ready to cook so
we'll head over to the stove and place
this over medium-high heat and all we
need to do here is bring this up to a
simmer stirring occasionally
and because we're making kind of a small
batch this is going to happen pretty
quick so don't walk away keep an eye on
it and like I said we're going to bring
that up to a simmer stirring and as it
starts to bubble you should notice that
will thicken up but just a little okay I
do not like this sauce too thick so I
tend not to add as much cornstarch to
some of the recipes but again that's up
to you you could add more if you want
and then basically as soon as our
mixture starts to simmer and thickens up
a little bit
we are done we can go ahead and remove
that from the heat and then while it's
still piping hot we will introduce our
fresh ingredients so we will toss in our
garlic as well as our minced Thai
chilies and then we'll take our whisk
and give that a mix and because this
mixture is still nice and hot that is
going to take some of the sharpness away
from the garlic but it's not going to
completely mellow it out as it would
have if we've added that stuff before we
simmered so we will go ahead and stir in
our chilies and garlic and then once
that's been incorporated the last step
at least for now is to add our fresh
lime juice
and we'll stir that in and that is
pretty much it for our sauce
except of course as always we're going
to have to taste and adjust for
seasoning but we can't do that yet
this sauce is way too hot to taste and I
don't mean physically because we're
going to serve this room temp that is
the temperature we need to taste it at
so what we're going to do is let this
cool down completely and then we will
check it out make sure it's tasting just
like we want so this is my sauce a
couple hours later completely cooled and
right here you can get a good look at
what I consider the perfect viscosity
you don't want a too thick or too thin
you basically want it perfect just like
this and now that is cooled we can take
a taste and adjust if we need to
ident because I always use exactly the
same amounts and then once we're happy
with how that tastes we can start
dipping things in that immediately or
transfer it into some kind of
appropriate container I chose this glass
jar because it's see-through
because I really want to show off what
is one incredibly gorgeous sauce in the
taste even on a plain spoon just
insanely delicious and other than having
to mince up some chilies and some garlic
very fast and easy to make and then if
we're not going to use all this up we
could just screw lid on and pop it in
the fridge where it should last for at
least a few weeks although I guarantee
nothing but anyway I can't go out on a
plain jar shot so let me put some of
these next to some fried spring rolls no
those are not homemade and then I'll
finish up by garnishing with a few of
those green chilies which I added
because I thought they look good in the
pictures but you know what that is a
stupid idea for garnish because those
really are too hot to eat raw and even
though you tell your guests that there's
always that one friend in every group
usually it's that guy that cuts the
sleeves off your shirts he'll go ahead
and try one because they're there and it
won't end well so while those chilies
are a bad idea what is a great idea is
to enjoy the sauce with some fried
spring rolls man that is good and by the
way if you're asking why would you make
a beautiful homemade sauce like that and
then serve it with frozen spring rolls
well unfortunately we've run out of time
for questions but speaking of frozen
spring rolls look what they included in
the box oh yeah a plastic pouch of sweet
chili sauce so which one are you gonna
serve it with this one did indicate you
love your guests
or this one that says I'm not even sure
I like you I think we all know the
answer to that so I really do hope you
give this amazing sauce a try soon head
over to food wishes calm for all the
ingredient amounts and more info as
usual and as always enjoy
